content:
Steve Coogan has a go
in our Reasonably-Priced Car.
Buying a used Nissan Skyline...

...and we give World Rally Champion,
Richard Burns, a taste of his own medicine.

But first, there's the launch
this month of a new British film

in which a very British hero
drives a very British car.

I am, of course,
talking about Harry Potter,

but since we couldn't get a Ford Anglia
in time for this week's show,

I thought we could have a look
at one of these instead.
It's the Aston Martin Vanquish,

and it's the kind of car
you wanna take to the Riviera.

But this is Britain,
so we don't have a Riviera.
So I took it to the Isle of Wight instead.

And here we are, in Cowes.
This is old school Britain,

shops selling heavy jumpers,
pubs selling heavy food.
So the Vanquish seems out of place.

It has a new type of chassis
which is, theoretically, very, very light,

and the body is made
of carbon fibre for the same reason.
You might imagine, then, that the Vanquish
is like modern British cuisine,
jus drizzled on to a spot of Rocket.

But no, it's a proper old
steak and kidney pie, this.
It actually weighs more than the DB7

and that's made of
angle grinders, and church pews.

The locals didn't seem unduly bothered
about the excess weight, though.

And that's the best thing
about driving a Vanquish.

Even though it costs £158,000,
everyone loves it.

How much house can you get
for that in the Isle of Wight?

Really? So let's have a look
at the Estate Agent's Window.

What have you got for the price
of Vanquish, then?
That house there?

Detached house, three bedrooms, lounge,
whatever one of those is.

Three bedroom house
for about the same as the Aston.

Would you rather have
that house or that car?

- The car.
- Good girl.
Definitely the car.

That's a six-litre,
460 horsepower, V12 engine.

You could attach that to your house
and still do 0 to 60 in five seconds.
So in a car...
Those bends. Oh.

Just hurls you out of the corners.
Just floor it and whaff! Bang!
Aw. That's a fast car,
that's a properly fast car.
So much power!

It's not just the power, either.
It's the noise.
Listen to this.
Oh, I could get all flowery now
and tell you it sounds like lightning,

but actually what it sounds like
is Tom Jones bending over

to pick up the soap while he's in
the showers in Wandsworth nick.
That noise. Ready?
It is a wonderful noise
and I love the way this car looks, too.
I love the interior, I like the badge.

I like the fact James Bond
has one. I like its Britishness.

You find yourself welling up
as you growl along
on a wave of nationalistic pride.
I vow to thee, my country.

It feels as though I'm driving around in
Douglas Bader himself.

But like Douglas Bader,
the Vanquish has something missing,
a gear lever. Look.

Instead, I've got these Formula One-style
paddles behind the steering wheel.

Right-hand side to change up,
left-hand side to change down.

That means you have to keep
both hands on the steering wheel
which is fine in Formula One.

No one talks on the phone
in Formula One, or eats.
You try doing a three-point turn.

Here, look, I've ran out
of island, I've got to do one.
So, er, reverse.

Pull both of them,
that's neutral. Push that.

Wait, no, still hasn't.
Yep, we've got reverse. Now.
Here we go, back up.
So I've got to get my foot off the brake,

and before we've rolled into the
Atlantic, I've got to hit the accelerator.
But I mustn't hit it too hard,

or I'll end up in the lifeboat hut,
doing about 140 mph.
So...

What a great gearbox.
What a wonderful invention.
Well done, whoever thought of this.
What was the matter with a manual?
Why do we have to have this?
There are other problems, too.

It judders in town,
and the clutch gives up completely

if you try to do
a full-bore standing start.

That means the Vanquish has to wade into
battle with one arm tied behind its back
and that's a problem.

Because look what's
attacking it these days.
This is the new Ferrari 575,

fitted here with an equally new
sports handling pack.

It costs about the same
as the Aston. Both are two-seaters,
both are front engine, rear-drive GT cars.
Both do nearly 200 miles an hour.
Both do 0 to 60 in under five seconds.
So, which is the best?

Well, let's talk to the man
who's driving the Ferrari.
Damon Hill.

- So, what's it like?
- It's beautiful.

- Really?
- Yeah. Yeah. It's just a lovely machine.
It's everything you expect from a Ferrari.

And it gives you that slight frisson,
you know, a slight nervousness.

- Scary even.
- It's like butterflies.

- Is it scary?
- Yeah.

I mean, you have to pay it
some respect, it's a prancing horse.

You know, you don't actually
feel completely comfortable in the car.

You're enjoying driving it,
but at the same time

you're very wary of
losing concentration on it.

Well, I tell you what,
you drive that now, I'll drive this.
Okay.
Meet up at the end, see what we think.

- And, erm, if I flash, okay...
- Yeah.

It means I want to come by.
If you just pull over,

- just get it out of the way, all right?
- Right. Okay.

And you really think
that is going to happen, do you?
What if I don't?

This has the same stupid gearbox
as the Aston Martin.

But unlike the Aston,
you don't have to have it.

You can save yourself £8,000,
£8,000... and have a proper manual.

It's a little difficult to use words like
awesome and very, very, very impressive
when you are used to Formula One cars.

Because after that everything else is
a little bit sluggish,

but for what it is, this is
a very, very impressive piece.

The nice thing is that you can
dawdle around in this car
minding your own business going slowly.
And then just drop a gear and suddenly...
You're in Schumacher mode.

I like to hear
the engine again. Take a listen to this.
Now it feels like a sports car.

Then with the driving over,
we met up to make a decision.

- The Ferrari.
- And for me.

- Ferrari.
- Yeah.
It's just more complete, somehow.

I think it gives you that shot
of adrenaline, doesn't it? Which...
...really, the Aston doesn't.

And then there is the power of that
Ferrari which is just immense, isn't it?

I don't think I can remember
ever having been in a road car
where my head's been thrown back.

- Really?
- You know, in second gear,
it just is doing that with your head.

I mean that has got
some serious acceleration on it.

- First, it has got 515 horse power.
- Yeah.

- But...
- And the Aston has only got 460.
Yeah, and the Aston's a lot heavier.

So one thing that kills
acceleration is weight.

The thing is, though,
there are certain aspects of the Vanquish

that I'd quite like to see
on the Ferrari. I love the way it looks.

- And the sound.
- And the noise.

I have to say, it actually disappointed me
when I got back in the Ferrari.

- It did.
- You couldn't hear anything.

Well, it sounds
like a Ford Fiesta.
But if you have those looks, and the noise,

and there's something that makes people
like you more if you're in an Aston.

I think you would be allowed
out of more side turns
than you would if you had the Ferrari,
when you are a bit of a Schumacher.
Hmm. We don't want that!

Jeremy,
you were doing 40 miles an hour there?

Absolutely. We never
exceeded the speed limit

once in the entire making
of that film there.

I have to say, though,
it was, for me, one of the greatest days,

honestly and truthfully. Ferrari,
Aston Martin, sun shone, Damon Hill.
It was just heaven.
And, what made it particularly exciting

was that the local Isle of Wight
radio station decided, in its wisdom,
to broadcast the fact over the air that.

Damon and Jeremy were down there
with an Aston and a Ferrari.

"Why don't you all go along
and have a look?"

So I came around the corner,
at 40 in the Ferrari,
and there he is with his hair greased down,

"I brought my dormer
down for you to have a look." Oh, God.

We then herded them
off the road. It was just heaven.

But you loved this, didn't you?
You loved the 575.

575 is a fabulous, fabulous car,
But it must be stressed,

the one that I drove there had
the Fiorano Handling Pack on it.
Which transforms the car, apparently.

Standard suspension,
a bit wallow-y, a bit soft.

- But this one was sporting the Aston box...
- Gearbox.
The gearbox, just, honestly...

- How bad was that?
- It just ruins it.
You just think just change it

'cause it's affecting
the second-hand values.

Oh yeah. I mean, if you went out
with a slug of money,
you'd struggle to buy a 575.
What's the waiting list on that now?

Well, at list price,
it's kind of 12-18 months.

- Really?
- Yeah.

I mean, if you want to pay a premium
you can get one before.

But with a Vanquish, I could get you one
next week list price.

- Really?
- Yeah.

And second-hand, whilst you will see them
advertised at strong money,

if you try to trade one in,
it's a different story.

The story of these cars
going six months old,
with, like, 50 grand depreciation.
So 170 new, 120 secondhhand.

So basically, then, the Ferrari is a
winner as far as an investment's concerned.

It's a winner on the road.
But, what about on the track?

It should be a foregone conclusion here
too, but The Stig had just bought himself.

So, we let him loose obviously
in the Aston Martin first of all.

Here he comes now... last little section,
coming across the line after Carpenters.
Corner here.

And it's one minute,
thirty-six seconds.

Now, into the Ferrari,
with his Boston CD again.

One minute, thirty-six to
beat. The final corner here.

Is he going to do it?
1:36, and...

Predictably, it is quicker
than the Aston, okay?
But, and this is amazing, by one second.

- Is that all?
- The time is 1:35.
Now I am going to put that on the board.
There they both are, behind the Noble.

But remember, it was...
I've underlined W for wet. It was that wet.
It really was horrendous out there.
Don't think that put The Stig off, though.
He really tried because this happened.

About 140 miles
an hour through this corner.

That's not bravery, doing that.
That's just stupidity.

Now, we've got a bit of
a Formula One theme going on tonight

which is why this has come
into our little world.

You see, Formula One teams are forever
telling us that the technology and gizmos

on their cars, eventually filter down
to the cars that you and I buy every day.

Well, on that basis,
we'd all be driving around now
in a 1998 McLaren as driven by Ayrton Senna
and, of course, we're not.
In fact, the only technology I can think of
that Formula One has given us

are those stupid gearboxes
that we don't want anyway.

Now, rallying, that's
a completely different animal.

Sure. It has contributed one
word to the English language.

Does anybody want to hazard
a guess what that word might be?
Anorak.
Anorak. You'd know, sir. You'd know.
Absolutely right. It's not an Eskimo word.

It's what people wear on the Welsh
hillsides when they are sitting in the rain.

But, rallying has given us
quite a lot more,
besides. Turbo charging. Four-wheel Drive.

And, if you walked into
a BMW showroom and said "Can I buy this,"
they'd say, "No. You can't."
But, you can buy a Mitsubishi Evo VII.
You can buy a Subaru Impreza.
And this has been going on for ages.

You could buy an Audi Quattro
or an Escort Cosworth or a Delta Integrale.
Rallying gives us the cars.

And there's something else
it gives us, a World Champion.

And he's here. Ladies
and Gentlemen, Richard Burns!

- How are you, Richard?
- Good.

So what are they going to do
about Formula One?
Erm, try to make it more interesting.
Try to make it as interesting as Rallying.

Well, that's it, you know,
'cause Rallying is always seen
as the poor relation, isn't it?
But actually, it's coming quite good now.

I think it is. There is
more manufacturers in it.

There's a lot more people
who can actually win a rally now
than there is in Formula One.

And I just... I hope that some of
the people who are...

Stopped watching that are
going to start watching this.

Yeah, that true. It's been kind
to you, let's be honest.

- Let's be honest.
- I was seeing two papers this week.

Twice as much you're earning
now as Jenson Button.

Oh, really? Well, I'm twice
as old as he is.
Yes.

- And you're a tax exile.
- I am.

- Got a house in Andorra.
- I have.

- Got a girlfriend.
- Yeah, which you need money for. Obviously.
Yes. And you've still got ginger hair.
You haven't spent any money there.

- Yeah, well, I did cut most of it off.
- Yeah.

Why do you drive one-handed?
That's what I can't understand.
It looks like you're really not trying.

I mean, put both hands
on the wheel, man. You'll go faster.
Got power steering. It's easy.

But why do you do it? You've always
just got one hand on the wheel.

I used to but now you've got the gear
change on the wheel then it's like...

- Oh, you haven't got that as well, have you?
- Sorry.
It's rubbish, it doesn't work.

- It does with me.
- That's why you've lost the championship.

Because of your gearbox.
Actually, no, why have you lost it?
Um, we've had a fairly average year

and our teammate has had a spectacular one.
Simple as that, really.

- We. No, you have.
- Me and Robert.

- We're a team.
- Oh, of course you are a team.

- I have to listen to him.
- Yeah, exactly.

And he caused you to have
a good crash, didn't he?
That was totally his fault. Yeah.

I had a quite big accident
a few weeks ago, in New Zealand.
Erm, when it was totally my fault.

The speed was right,
but the corner was too tight.

When you were younger,
you didn't like going to pubs and discos,

and you preferred the company
of Rally people.
Yeah, but then I grew up,

and I had that money
you were talking about,
and found out what all that was about.
So now I do go to the pub.

To be honest, I think if you don't allow
yourself to live a slightly normal life,

you're going to want to shoot yourself
fairly quickly, I would think.

Well exactly. I mean, I saw a picture of
your great rival Colin McRae the other day

tucking in on a race to
a curry sauce and chips.

Now, I've never seen
a Formula One driver going,
"I'll have the curry sauce on that."
They are not cultured enough.

Anyway, of course,
it's the, erm... what's it called now?
Network Q Rally GB.

...starts next,
well, later this week, isn't it?

- Yeah.
- What day is it?

- Starts on Friday. Yeah.
- Friday. Okay.

- And you've won that three times.
- Three times.
You've done your research.

You sit in the car, you've got a heater,
haven't you?

- We've got a heater.
- So you are quite comfortable.

Have you ever thought,
what would it be like... come with me.
Have you ever thought what would it be like

for the people who have
to turn up and spectate on the rally?
I remember, I did... I used to do that.

- You did?
- Yeah.

Well, I'm not sure whether you have really
got it at the forefront of your head.

So I want to give you a flavour of what it
is to be like to be a rally spectator, okay?

So if you would just like
to step out there. Thanks very much.
Right, um...
Now, we'll leave him out there
until his whole head's turned blue.

What about a car that's got
nothing to do with Formula One,
and nothing to do with Rallying?
The Nissan Skyline.

It's basically a huge PlayStation, with
an exhaust pipe on the back.

And if you're interested
in buying a secondhand one,
there's a few things you need to know.
In the world league table of supercars,

Japan has only made one real contribution,
the Nissan Skyline.

It may not have the looks and the pedigree
of an Aston Martin or Ferrari,

but then again, it never had
the price tag, either.
But it certainly had the pace.

Wherever it went racing,
it crushed the opposition.

In fact, in the Australian
Touring Car series

they changed the rules
so the car could be outlawed.
The Skyline's strength lies under the skin
where you'll find a 276-brake horsepower,

twin turbo, and an incredible
computer-controlled chassis

that can be two-wheel drive
when you want it
and four-wheel drive when you need it.
But it's all over for this Techno titan

because this year
they stopped building Skylines.

And Japan's cut-price supercar
is now available only as a secondhand buy.

In all, there were three models
to choose from,

the R32 which was built
in the first half of the '90s,

the R33 which comes around
from '96 to '99,
and finally, the imaginatively-named R34.
Which, with a 0 to 60 time of 5.2 seconds,

and a top speed of 155 miles per hour,
was the best of the breed.
That was nice.
Not only is it blisteringly quick,
but it's almost idiot-proof to drive

with that computerised chassis capable of
turning Maureen into Michael Schumacher.

A really clever tool converter,
you've got active dual control.
There are sensors all around on the wheels

and gyroscopes telling how fast you
are cornering and accelerating.

They chuck all that information
into a 16-bit processor

and the outcome is, the car
kind of looks after you.
It doesn't half make a corner quick.

What about the display here?
Look at this. Ooh!
As we drive along,

we can check how many G
we are going round corners.
We can check the, er, turbo boost.

We can check the torque
to the front wheels.

I mean, it is going to keep you
occupied for, what... minutes!
Fantastic bit of kit.

It really is a car for
the PlayStation generation.

Big fan of the car.
We all are, obviously, great car.
Which one should you buy?

Well, the first thing you've got to realise
about the Skylines

is that, they're mainly
bought as playthings.

So if you get on looking at one,
you can find a car with quite low mileage

that's got, like, three or four
owners on it.

Because basically, they wheel it out,
do a track day, drive it home.
So you've got to understand that.

And the other thing is,
you've got to be aware

- that a lot of them are grey imports.
- Yeah.

And the problem is, when you bring
a car in from Japan,

yeah, but you kind of you lose the
service books and you often lose mileages.
They have a little hair cut on the mileage.
Yeah, a little haircut, a little trim.

Somewhere coming round past Dubai, I'll
just trim a couple of thousand miles off.

- That's what's happening is it, with them?
- Well... Yeah, it is. It is.
Okay, and so what should you look for?
What kind of things are they known for?

Well, I mean, they're
a well-put-together car

and a lot of things about them
are very, very good

but depending on the model
there are things that do go wrong.

The R32s, for example, the brake discs
on them sometimes explode.

- Erm...
- Explode?

- Explode, yes.
- What, bang?
Bang. Just... well, kind of disintegrate,
and they are 500 quid a pair to replace.

- You don't want that.
- Don't want that.
On the later cars, on the 33s,

you also get synchro problems
on the gearbox on third and fifth.

Erm, you can sort it, but it's going
to cost you about £1,000.
Okay. And this one, the 34?
The 34 is pretty much bullet-proof.

- Really?
- Yeah. But it's a lot of money to buy.

- Is it? How much is it?
- Yeah.

You are looking at £40,000
for one of these.
Well, that's the cheapest it'll go?

- At the moment, about £40,000 for a UK car.
- Really?

Yeah. I mean, it'll drop.
But at the moment...
And what about the question of tuning them?

'Cause most of them... and I've driven one
that's got 1,000 horsepower.

Yeah. Well, I mean, the standard car
has got 276 brake horsepower,
which, to be fair, is plenty.
The minute you start putting chips on them,

you're going to start getting
turbo wear.

The normal turbo will last
about 60,000 miles,

and it costs you about
£1,500 to replace. Twin turbos.

The minute you put a chip on that,
you start bumping that power up,

you're going to shorten
the life of that turbo.

So you really want to try
and find one that is unchipped, unmolested.

- Yeah. As standard as possible.
- Which is actually pretty hard.

And one other thing to note on these
things... obviously, a four-wheel drive

and when you are checking the tyres, see
the tyres on these are about £250 a piece.

- So that's £1000 for all four corners.
- Thousand pounds for a set.

And the other thing is,
the way the geometry is on the Skyline.

They don't wear out on the outside of
the tyre, they wear out on the inside.

- So like an Escort Cosworth?
- Just like an Escort.

5000 mile on an Escort Cosworth,
tyres have gone on the inside.

Yeah. The thing is, when people look
at tyres, they normally just go,
"Okay, yeah, there's some tread on that."

So what you need to do is,
turn it right on full lock,

get your hand in there,
feel the inside, feel the tread on that.

- 'Cause otherwise you're in to £1,000.
- Hmm. Good tip.

- Okay, so we've got the 32, 33, 34?
- Yeah.

- Which one do you reckon?
- Well, the 32 you can pick up for about ten, twelve grand,

but, to be fair, they are
quite long in the tooth now,
they are quite old cars.
Erm... the 33, well yeah.

You can pick one of those up
for about 20 grand.
And the 34, as I say, is 40 grand.
So probably on balance
the best value car is going to be the 33.

'Cause it's about the same
as the 34, isn't it?

Yeah, absolutely same brakes, Brembo
brakes, same engine, same twin turbo.

Okay, a little bit older but, you know,
it's half the price.
Half the price. Brilliant.

- Let's do some news.
- Okay.

The News this week for
petrolheads dominated largely
by the continuing saga of Formula One,
and how to make it more interesting.

And what they've decided, as far as
the racing is concerned, is to do nothing.

- At all?
- No.

They're just going to sit there
with their fingers crossed.

- It might get better.
- And hope it's more interesting.

A couple of weeks ago you came up
with a theory, though, to improve it

which was basically to get rid
of all the electronic gizmos,

- and effectively give us F1 Unplugged.
- Yeah.

- That's not a bad idea.
- Yeah, but we've got a better idea.
What you've got to do is

you've one point
for qualifying on pole, yeah?
You've one point for winning the race.
And then you have a point

- every time you overtake someone.
- Yeah.

It's brilliant. You see, the thing is.
It is brilliant, this.

Michael Schumacher would
still be World Champion.
He'd qualify on pole, get a point,

then at the start of the race
he'd have to engage fourth,
slow start, drop to the back,

then he would spend the next two hours
overtaking everyone.
We see overtaking manoeuvres.

- Perfect.
- It's brilliant.

Yeah but, if, Coulthard
and all the frontrunners are slowing up.
Yeah.

Conceivably, some idiot in a Minardi
could wait and...

And by the first corner they got 20 points
in the bag, take everybody.

Yeah, it would be better to
start at the back, wouldn't it?
So the qualifying would be funny.

It would be how slowly
could you drive round.

But then may be the lights would go
green and no one would go anywhere at all.

You're right.
They'd just be sitting there.

The lights have gone green.
It's a good job.

Murray Walker wouldn't still
be commentating on this one.

And, no, hang on, because they would
the lights would go green.
Nobody would move at all.

- And you'd sit and then it would be chicken.
- Yeah.

I am going to go now
now, now, the first corner.

- There would be great crashes.
- It won't work.

- It won't work.
- No.
Here is one, you might have seen this.
This lad... 19-year-old lad.

He's just got out of jail, he's got one
of those electronic tags on.

He's been joyriding so much,
stealing so many cars.

So he's under curfew,
he can't go anywhere. Erm...

He has just won £9.7 million
on the lottery.

- And your point is?
- Well, my point is this, frankly, Jeremy,
that and that alone proves there is no God.

Talking of God, we put a request out
last week for men of the cloth

to get in touch if they wanted to come
and drive round our track

'cause we're looking for
the world's fastest religion, yeah?
Erm...

No, really we are. And we have had a lot
of email responses.
This could do the world good.
There is a particularly good one here

from The Reverend
Danny Wignall,

who writes to say that
he wants to give it a try,

and by the way, "Did you know
that Jesus drove a Honda?" he says.

Jesus says in John's Gospel
chapter 12 verse 49,

"For I did not speak
of my own Accord, but..."

There is a man
who knows his Bible.
No, no, it gets better. The Reverend...

The Reverend Philip Sutton
is also keen to come on the show.

He says that King David...
driving fast is a fine biblical tradition,

for the Bible makes clear
that King David rode a British motorbike.

The quote is "The roar of David's Triumph
was heard throughout the land."

The thing is, though, they're all kind
of Anglican. They are all Vicars.

Erm, now we've got
one Methodist, which is good.
We're okay for Hindus.

We've even had the Hare Krishna,
which is good.
But we are still down on Rabbis
and we are down on Imams...

- Buddhists.
- No, we're okay for Buddhists.
It's basically, we are down on Rabbis.
So if you are a Rabbi, come and have a go.

- Excellent.
- Okay.

This week's insider dealing.
Well, it's a funny old time of year

because by this time of year,
all the manufacturers are looking back
and saying, "Well, we had this target,

"we had this objective
to sell this many cars this year.

"We're seven weeks
from the end of the year.
"Are we gonna hit our targets?"

And they're all sort of...
They are all hanging on to see if they will

but what will happen,
and it happens every year,

in the next couple or three weeks
